childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1979-1991

The smell of Big Wheel tires on hot pavement. The satisfying chunk of a Fisher-Price record player dropping its needle. The glow of a wood-paneled console TV warming up for Saturday morning cartoons. Childhood had a texture kids today will never know—everything was heavy, physical, and slightly dangerous in ways that built character.

At two, MTV launched, and music videos became the wallpaper of childhood. Children absorbed 'Thriller' during formative brain development—the zombies, the red jacket, the dance moves children tried to imitate in living rooms. By five, children knew every word to 'Like a Virgin' without understanding any of them. Madonna and Michael Jackson weren't just musicians. They were the visual language of Gen X.

Saturday mornings were sacred. Smurfs at 8:00, Muppet Babies at 8:30, Dungeons & Dragons at 9:00. Children ate Pac-Man cereal from plastic bowls, still in pajamas, parents blissfully asleep. The TV Guide was scripture. Missing a show meant missing it forever—no DVR, no streaming, no second chances.

Gen X were latchkey kids, probably. Home alone after school because both parents worked, or there was only one parent. Gen X let itself in with keys on strings around necks, microwaved Hot Pockets, and watched DuckTales until someone came home. Gen X knew not to answer the door for strangers. Gen X knew how to dial 911. Independence wasn't a parenting philosophy. It was just Tuesday.

Toys had heft. GI Joe with the kung-fu grip. My Little Pony with hair children could brush. Transformers that actually transformed (badly, but still). The Cabbage Patch Kid children waited in line for, with its adoption certificate and unique name. Parents paid scalper prices at Toys 'R' Us and children never knew. Garbage Pail Kids were collected until teachers confiscated them. Children had strong opinions about whether the Thundercats could beat the He-Man crew.

At seven, the Challenger exploded. Teachers wheeled in TVs because Christa McAuliffe, a teacher, was going to space. Then everyone watched her die. The adults didn't know what to say. Children learned something that day about how the world could break right in front of them, and how grown-ups didn't have all the answers.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen X Generation

Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. The forgotten middle child of American generations. Too young to be Boomers, too old to be Millennials, perpetually overlooked by marketers and politicians who prefer larger demographics. There are about 65 million Gen Xers, making Gen X the smallest generation since the Silent Generation. Sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials. Nobody makes movies about Gen X's childhood. Nobody writes think pieces about Gen X's avocado toast. At this point, Gen X prefers the invisibility.

Gen X was twelve when the Berlin Wall fell. Gen X watched it on TV—crowds with sledgehammers, champagne spraying, strangers embracing on a wall that had defined parents' entire adult lives. For parents, it was the end of an existential threat. For Gen X, it was history homework that happened to occur in real time. The Cold War was Gen X's childhood's background radiation, and then it just... stopped.

Gen X spans 1965 to 1980—the post-Boomer bust years, when birth rates cratered and divorce rates spiked. Gen X is the children of the sexual revolution's hangover. Half Gen X's friends came from broken homes. 'Latchkey kid' wasn't just a term; it was Gen X's after-school reality. Gen X raised itself on TV, video games, and whatever trouble Gen X could find in the neighborhood. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given.

The 1991 recession hit when Gen X was twelve—parents stressed about mortgages and layoffs while Gen X watched the Gulf War on CNN. By the time Gen X graduated high school, Gen X had already learned that jobs weren't guaranteed and pensions weren't coming. Gen X's career began in the go-go '90s, but Gen X never quite trusted the boom. Gen X had seen too many busts already.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, Gen X was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Gen X is sandwiched between the Boomers who won't retire and the Millennials who can't afford to start. Gen X has been running companies and raising kids while both larger generations get all the attention. Gen X is used to being ignored. It's actually kind of restful. Gen X can still entertain itself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year Gen X was born, disco finally died. Literally—'Disco Demolition Night' at Comiskey Park saw thousands of records exploded on the field, a riot of middle-American resentment. The Knack had everyone singing 'My Sharona' whether they wanted to or not. The Clash dropped London Calling, and punk's second wave began. Michael Jackson released Off the Wall, a warm-up for the domination that would define Gen X's childhood. Hip-hop entered the mainstream with the Sugarhill Gang's 'Rapper's Delight.' The musical world was reshuffling itself, and Gen X would absorb all of it.

Gen X's actual pop culture education started with MTV's first decade. At two, Gen X watched 'Video Killed the Radio Star' launch an era. By five, Gen X had memorized the choreography from 'Thriller' and debated whether Michael Jackson or Prince was cooler. (The answer was Prince, but Gen X didn't know it yet.) Cyndi Lauper, Duran Duran, A-ha's 'Take On Me'—these weren't just songs. They were the visual vocabulary of Gen X's childhood, music inseparable from image.

Saturday mornings were serious business. Gen X had appointment viewing for Voltron, Transformers, He-Man, G.I. Joe, and She-Ra (if Gen X had sisters, or if Gen X was secretly into it itself). These weren't just cartoons—they were 22-minute toy commercials, and they worked perfectly. Gen X begged for the action figures. Parents complied, grudgingly.

At six, Gen X saw The Goonies and understood that kids could have adventures without adults. At eight, Who Framed Roger Rabbit blew Gen X's minds with its cartoon-human hybrid. At ten, Gen X was watching The Simpsons before parents realized it wasn't for kids. By twelve, Nirvana's Nevermind hit and suddenly everything Gen X had grown up with felt obsolete. Grunge replaced synth-pop. Flannel replaced neon. Cynicism replaced optimism. Gen X was thirteen, and the culture had shifted to meet Gen X exactly where Gen X was—alienated, anxious, and ready to pretend Gen X didn't care.

The John Hughes trilogy shaped Gen X's teenage expectations: The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Pretty in Pink. Gen X understood detention, suburban ennui, and the agony of unrequited crush. At fifteen, Pulp Fiction made nonlinear storytelling cool and quotable. At sixteen, Gen X saw Reality Bites and felt seen, even though Gen X knew Ethan Hawke's character was insufferable. Gen X was the first generation to treat irony as a native language.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The Sony Walkman launched in 1979—portable music for the masses, foam headphones that leaked sound to everyone nearby. It cost $200 in 1979 dollars, which meant parents didn't have one, but older kids at the mall did. By the time Gen X was old enough to want one, they cost $30 and came in neon colors. Gen X listened to dubbed cassettes of dubbed cassettes, generations of hiss layered over Bon Jovi.

At three, Gen X probably played first video games—Atari 2600, if families had one. Pitfall, Space Invaders, Adventure with its infamous hidden Easter egg. The graphics were blocks. The sound was beeps. It was magic. At four, Gen X got Ataris or ColecoVisions for Christmas, and parents couldn't pry Gen X away from the TV.

Gen X was six when the Macintosh launched with that famous 1984 Super Bowl ad. The Apple II was already in some schools—Oregon Trail, where Gen X died of dysentery every single time. By eight, schools had computer labs with green-screen monitors and that distinctive hum of spinning disk drives. Gen X learned to type on actual typewriters first, then transitioned to word processors.

The format wars defined Gen X's media consumption. VHS vs. Betamax (VHS won). Cassette vs. 8-track (cassette won, barely). Gen X recorded songs off the radio, fingers hovering over the pause button to avoid the DJ's voice. Gen X made mix tapes with handwritten labels, tiny acts of curation and devotion. When CDs arrived in elementary school, they felt like science fiction—no rewinding, no degradation, perfect sound forever.

At seventeen, Windows 95 dropped with lines around the block. The internet arrived in Gen X's late teens—AOL dial-up, the screech of a modem handshake, 'You've Got Mail' as actual excitement. Chat rooms where Gen X typed 'A/S/L?' to strangers. GeoCities websites with spinning graphics and MIDI music. Gen X remembers when getting online meant nobody could use the phone. Gen X remembers when checking email was a destination, not a constant state.

Gen X is analog-native but digitally fluent. Gen X can read a map, use a card catalog, remember phone numbers. Gen X adapted to every technological shift because Gen X had to—from cassettes to CDs to MP3s to streaming, from letters to email to texts to Slack. Smartphones arrived when Gen X was nearly thirty, and Gen X adopted them without making them Gen X's identity. Gen X knows what boredom feels like. Gen X knows how to be alone with Gen X's thoughts. These are rare skills now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The Iran hostage crisis began in 1979—52 Americans held captive for 444 days while parents watched the nightly news count each one. Three Mile Island partially melted down five months before Gen X's birth, making nuclear power a punchline and an anxiety. The Soviets invaded Afghanistan, beginning a conflict that would shape American foreign policy for decades. Welcome to Earth. Things were already complicated.

At two, Reagan was shot outside the Hilton and survived. Gen X doesn't remember it, but parents do—the confusion, the Alexander Haig 'I'm in charge' moment, the sense that anything could happen. At four, the Beirut barracks bombing killed 241 American servicemembers. At five, Bhopal killed thousands in India. The world kept delivering disasters on a schedule Gen X was too young to understand.

At seven, the Challenger exploded. Teachers stopped class to watch because Christa McAuliffe was aboard—a teacher going to space! Then seventy-three seconds later, Gen X watched her die on live television. Nobody knew what to say. The teachers cried. Gen X went to recess anyway. That disconnect between trauma and routine became familiar.

At ten, the Berlin Wall fell. Gen X watched people with sledgehammers chip away at concrete that had divided families for decades. The Cold War ended not with nuclear fire but with souvenir hunters. At twelve, the Soviet Union collapsed entirely. The existential threat of Gen X's childhood just... dissolved. It felt anticlimactic after all those duck-and-cover drills.

At twelve, the Gulf War began—the first war televised in real-time, night-vision footage over Baghdad that looked exactly like a video game. This was intentional. At sixteen, OJ Simpson's white Bronco stopped the nation. At seventeen, the Oklahoma City bombing—domestic terrorism that didn't fit the foreign-enemy narrative Gen X had been raised on. The enemy was already inside the house.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, Gen X was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Gen X remembers exactly where Gen X was. Gen X remembers the confusion, the fear, the ash-covered people walking across bridges. The world before that day and the world after are different countries. Gen X has now lived most of Gen X's adult life in the after. Gen X remembers when Gen X could meet people at the airport gate. Gen X remembers when we weren't always at war.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Gen X graduated high school around 1997, college around 2001 if Gen X went. The dot-com boom was in full swing—tech companies with no revenue were worth billions, stock options were the new currency, 23-year-olds drove Porsches to their 'Senior Vice President of Vibes' positions. Gen X may have gotten in on that. Gen X may have watched it from the outside, wondering what Gen X was doing wrong. Then April 2000 arrived, and the bubble popped so hard it echoed for years.

Gen X's early career was whiplash. The late '90s offered jobs everywhere—come work for a startup, get stock options, disrupt something. By 2001, those same companies were sending mass layoff emails from AOL accounts. Gen X learned early that corporate loyalty was a myth. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. Job security became an oxymoron.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. Maybe Gen X had just bought houses, maybe Gen X was about to. Maybe Gen X lost those houses. The market dropped 40%. Maybe Gen X lost the retirement funds Gen X had barely started building. Gen X definitely lost faith in the system that was supposed to reward hard work and playing by the rules. The rules, Gen X noticed, didn't apply to the people who broke the economy.

Gen X has worked in cubicle farms with fluorescent lights, then open offices with exposed brick and ping-pong tables. Gen X has sent faxes, written memos, adapted to email, Slack, and whatever comes next. Dress codes went from suits to business casual to hoodies to Zoom-from-the-waist-up. Gen X adapted to everything because adapting is what Gen X does.

Gen X is in middle management now, probably. Or senior individual contributor. Or running something. Gen X is managing Millennials who want purpose and feedback, hiring Gen Z who have side hustles and no illusions, reporting to Boomers who won't retire and keep suggesting Gen X 'really commit to the company.' Gen X has been at this long enough to see through the corporate platitudes. 'We're a family' means unpaid overtime. 'Unlimited vacation' means zero vacation. Gen X does the job anyway because what else is there.

COVID proved Gen X could work from anywhere. Now Gen X is expected to work from everywhere, all the time, Slack pinging at midnight because someone in a different time zone has a 'quick question.' The boundary between work and life isn't blurred. It's gone. Gen X's laptop bag is always packed. The office is in Gen X's pocket. Gen X didn't complain about it—Gen X just did the work. That's Gen X's legacy: competence without fanfare.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Gen X is the last generation that dated without algorithms. This cohort met people at parties, through friends, in line at coffee shops, at record stores flipping through the same section. Phone numbers were exchanged on napkins. Calls went to answering machines—those actual machines with tiny cassettes—and decisions had to be made: leave a message or hang up and try again, knowing the click would be recorded either way.

Gen X learned to flirt through physical proximity. Gen X memorized crushes' class schedules so Gen X could 'accidentally' walk past them. Gen X passed notes in class, folded into elaborate origami shapes. Gen X spent hours on phones with cords stretched into closets for privacy, talking about nothing, comfortable in the silence. Connection took effort, took time, took presence. It meant something because it had to.

Gen X's relationship education came from John Hughes movies and less wholesome sources. Gen X learned about longing from Say Anything—John Cusack and the boombox, which is now a restraining order waiting to happen. Gen X learned about dysfunction from parents' generation, who divorced at record rates and taught Gen X that love wasn't permanent. Half Gen X's friends came from broken homes. Gen X swore Gen X would do better, or Gen X swore Gen X would never get married at all.

Match.com launched when Gen X was eighteen, but online dating was embarrassing then—something desperate people did. Gen X met partners the old-fashioned way: bars, parties, friends of friends, work (before HR made that complicated). By the time Tinder arrived in 2012, Gen X was thirty-three and possibly already married or divorced. The app-based dating economy happened around Gen X, not to Gen X. Gen X watched younger people swipe their way through relationships and felt like an anthropologist observing a foreign culture.

Gen X has the highest divorce rate in American history, which tracks. Gen X learned from experts. But Gen X is also more likely to marry later or not at all, having watched the institution fail parents. If Gen X did marry, Gen X probably divorced and tried again. Or Gen X stayed, working at it, because Gen X had seen what giving up looked like.

Gen X friendships span decades and time zones. Gen X has moved for school, for work, for cheaper rent, for love that didn't work out. Gen X maintains relationships through group texts that have been active for twenty years, where nobody needs context because everyone lived it together. Gen X knows how to be close to people who are far away. Distance doesn't mean disconnection. Gen X has had a lot of practice.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Parents remember stagflation—the 1970s nightmare of high inflation and high unemployment simultaneously, which economists said couldn't happen until it did. Mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s. Gen X grew up in its aftermath, watching parents stretch paychecks and argue about bills. Money was always slightly scarce, slightly stressful, even when things were okay. Gen X inherited that anxiety without inheriting the cause.

The dot-com boom hit when Gen X was twenty, and suddenly money seemed like a game anyone could win. Friends from college were paper millionaires. Stock options were compensation. 'IPO' was the most exciting three letters in the language. Then March 2000 arrived, and Pets.com was worthless, and all those paper millionaires were just paper again. Gen X learned: what goes up comes down, usually faster.

Gen X bought houses before they became impossible—maybe in Gen X's late twenties, maybe early thirties. A starter home for $180,000 that's now worth $450,000, except Gen X can't access that wealth without selling it and having nowhere to live. Maybe Gen X lost those houses in 2008 when the market dropped 40% and Gen X's adjustable-rate mortgages adjusted and Gen X's jobs disappeared and banks didn't care about Gen X's circumstances. Either way, Gen X understands that real estate isn't always a safe investment, which is wisdom Millennials would kill for.

The great wealth transfer everyone talks about keeps getting delayed. Gen X's parents are living longer, spending more on healthcare, maybe needing Gen X's financial help instead of providing theirs.

Three major economic crashes hit during Gen X's prime earning years. Gen X is in Gen X's peak earning years now, which is good, because Gen X is also the sandwich generation—supporting aging parents who didn't save enough and adult children who can't afford to launch. Gen X is funding college tuitions for kids while paying for assisted living for parents while trying to save for a retirement that keeps receding into the distance. The math doesn't quite work, but Gen X keeps running the numbers anyway.

Gen X's relationship with money is pragmatic rather than optimistic. Gen X has seen three major crashes before fifty—dot-com, 2008, COVID. Gen X keeps emergency funds because Gen X has needed them. Gen X diversifies because Gen X has watched concentrated positions evaporate. Gen X doesn't trust the market to keep rising, but Gen X doesn't trust mattress cash either. Gen X saves what Gen X can and hopes it's enough, knowing it probably isn't, doing it anyway because what else can Gen X do.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

Gen X's ironic detachment was armor, and Gen X has forgotten Gen X is still wearing it. Gen X learned early that caring gets Gen X hurt—caring about institutions that fail, about jobs that lay Gen X off, about relationships that end. So Gen X cultivated a protective distance, a running commentary of 'whatever' and 'it's all meaningless anyway.' The problem is that armor can become a cage. Some things actually matter, and pretending they don't just lets bad situations get worse.

Gen X is so self-reliant that Gen X has forgotten how to ask for help. The latchkey kid who made their own dinner at eight is now the adult who handles everything alone even when they're drowning. Gen X considers asking for help a weakness, or an imposition, or simply something that doesn't occur to Gen X. Gen X will burn out before Gen X will delegate. This isn't strength; it's a trauma response masquerading as competence.

Gen X's skepticism of institutions can tip into nihilism. Yes, systems are broken. Yes, politicians lie. Yes, corporations exploit. Gen X has been paying attention since Watergate—Gen X was a baby, but Gen X inherited the cynicism. But dismissing everything as corrupt means never building anything better. Younger generations are out there creating alternatives while Gen X is explaining why nothing works. Being right about the brokenness doesn't fix the brokenness.

Gen X underestimates how hard things have gotten because Gen X survived hard things too. Gen X worked Gen X's way up, bought houses on normal salaries, built careers through the recessions. So why can't they? This ignores the actual math: housing costs tripled relative to income since Gen X was buying. College costs quadrupled. Healthcare costs, childcare costs, everything costs more in ways that aren't about avocado toast or work ethic. The ladder Gen X climbed got pulled up behind Gen X, and sometimes Gen X forgets Gen X is standing on the platform.

Gen X's pop culture references are dated, and Gen X doesn't always notice. Gen X quotes movies from 1985 to people born in 2000 and is surprised when they don't laugh. The Breakfast Club is ancient history to them. 'Don't You (Forget About Me)' is an oldies song. The generation gap exists even when Gen X doesn't feel old, and pretending it doesn't makes Gen X seem out of touch rather than timeless.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: Gen X has accepted too much. Gen X adjusted to every crisis, every broken promise, every moved goalpost. Gen X are survivors, which is admirable, but survival shouldn't be the ceiling. Gen X got so good at adapting that Gen X stopped asking whether Gen X should have to. The flexibility that served Gen X well has also made Gen X complicit in systems that shouldn't require this much flexibility to navigate.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Gen X's 20s (1999-2009): The decade of whiplash. Gen X started in the dot-com gold rush—IPOs, stock options, Aeron chairs in converted loft offices. Then the bubble burst in 2000, and the optimism evaporated overnight. Gen X was twenty-two on September 11th, old enough for adult responsibilities, young enough for Gen X's worldview to crack and reform around the trauma. The early 2000s job market was brutal. By twenty-nine, Gen X might have been buying houses, getting married, starting families—and then 2008 hit and the floor dropped out. Gen X learned early that the script parents followed (graduate, get job, buy house, retire) wasn't available to Gen X.

Gen X's 30s (2009-2019): Rebuilding. Gen X picked up the pieces from 2008 while everyone argued about whose fault it was. (It was the banks. It was always the banks.) Gen X hit career stride in Gen X's early thirties, got promoted, maybe switched companies a few times because loyalty wasn't rewarded. Gen X watched smartphones take over daily life—Instagram filtered everything, Twitter accelerated everything, Facebook got weird. If Gen X had kids, they grew up in a world Gen X didn't fully understand, screens everywhere, content consumption as lifestyle. Gen X probably felt old for the first time somewhere in here, citing a movie from Gen X's childhood and getting blank stares.

Gen X's 40s (2019-2029): Gen X is in this decade now, probably reading this somewhere in the middle of it. COVID hit when Gen X was forty or forty-one, reshaping work, relationships, and daily life. Gen X pivoted to remote work, homeschooled kids, dealt with parents who couldn't be visited in nursing homes. Gen X is in senior roles now, managing across generations, wondering when Boomers will finally retire. Gen X's kids are teenagers or older—needing less physical care, more emotional guidance. Gen X's parents are aging, needing more. Gen X is the fulcrum of the family, holding everything together while processing Gen X's own mortality for the first time in an immediate way.

Gen X's 50s (2029-2039): Peak authority, probably. Gen X will be the senior generation at work as the last Boomers exit. Gen X will mentor Gen Z and Gen Alpha, trying not to sound like parents did. Gen X's kids will be adults, possibly having kids of their own, making Gen X grandparents. Gen X's parents will be in their eighties or nineties, if they're still here—healthcare decisions, estate planning, grief. This is the decade where Gen X either coasts on what Gen X has built or blows it up and starts over. Both choices are valid. Most people do a bit of both.

Gen X's 60s and beyond (2039+): Retirement age, though retirement won't look like parents' version. Social Security will exist, probably, but benefits may be adjusted. Gen X will have lived through the entire arc from analog to digital to whatever comes next. Climate change will have reshaped geography. The world will be unrecognizable. Gen X will tell younger people about the Cold War, about life before smartphones, about MTV when it played music. They'll listen politely and not quite believe it was really like that. It'll sound like science fiction in reverse—a world without constant connectivity, without GPS, without the internet. Gen X lived there. Gen X remembers. And that perspective, however useless it seems, is Gen X's to give.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US in 1979. Gen X is part of the 65 million Americans classified as Gen X—the smallest generation since the Silent Generation, perpetually overshadowed by the 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials on either side of Gen X. Gen X is the middle child of American generations. Gen X has made peace with it.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): Boomers got the postwar boom, the pensions, the affordable houses, the secure jobs, the social contracts that actually held. Gen X got the aftermath. Gen X graduated into recessions, adapted to corporate restructuring, watched pensions convert to 401(k)s that put all the risk on Gen X. Boomers bought starter homes for $30,000 that appreciated to $500,000 while Gen X was still saving for down payments. Gen X is poorer than Boomers were at Gen X's age despite working just as hard. The difference isn't effort. It's timing. It's rigged math masquerading as meritocracy.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): Gen X is more cynical but also more stable. Gen X bought houses before they cost half a million dollars. Gen X built careers before the gig economy made everything precarious. Gen X is skeptical where Millennials are earnest, guarded where Millennials are vulnerable. Gen X makes jokes where Millennials make demands. Gen X has given up on changing the system; Millennials are still trying. Sometimes Millennials' hope looks naive. Sometimes Gen X's resignation looks complicit. Both are probably right.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Gen X and Gen Z are from different planets. Gen X remembers life before the internet, before smartphones, before everything was documented and uploaded and permanent. Gen Z doesn't. Gen Z has never known a world without screens, without social media, without the constant awareness of being perceived. Gen X's ironic detachment looks like apathy to Gen Z. Gen Z's earnest activism looks naive to Gen X. But Gen Z is inheriting problems Gen X's generation helped create—climate change accelerating, housing impossible, institutions crumbling—so maybe Gen X should cut Gen Z some slack. Gen Z is building in the rubble.

Gen X's life expectancy is 76-78 years, slightly improved from previous generations but starting to flatten. Substance-related health challenges—suicide, overdose, alcoholism—hit Gen X harder than anyone expected. The 'slacker' stereotype was always wrong, but the pain underneath it was real. Gen X internalized failure as personal rather than systemic. Gen X self-medicated through economic anxieties nobody was naming. This catches up.

But Gen X is also adaptable, resourceful, and underrated. Gen X survived latchkey childhoods, Cold War anxiety, multiple economic crashes, and the complete transformation of technology. Gen X raised kids, managed careers, held families together without instruction manuals. Gen X is comfortable with uncertainty because uncertainty is all Gen X has known. The world keeps changing, and Gen X keeps adjusting. It's not glamorous, but it's Gen X's.
